subject: Re: [junit] Re: Any plans to revamp junit?
msgSnippet: ... Well, no, it isn t flawed at all; but I respect your right to disagree. The statement all serious people have their own test runner is just downright
messageBody:
Vlad Roubtsov wrote:

> > if x is a person, and S x is "x is serious" and R x
> > is "x has his own
> > test runner", then the claim is...
> >
> > forall x (S x -> R x)
> >
> > By the law of specialization, in particular, if j
> > means yours truly (and
> > yes, I am a person), then
> >
> > S j -> R j
> >
> > However, I don't have my own test runner, so
>
> To finish this (slightly) amusing logic discourse,
> your argument is flawed again, because the "I don't
> have my own test runner" fact was not asserted by you
> prior to this. You may have known it all along, but
> not the rest of us.

Well, no, it isn't flawed at all; but I respect your right to disagree.
The statement "all serious people have their own test runner" is just
downright absurd. In general, such generalizations are specious at best.
This is a specific instance. (That said, I'm guilty of plenty of
premature generalization.)

> > The problem is, I am /quite/ serious, having spent a
> > year writing about
> > it and all that. Say whatever you want about the
> > quality of the work,
> > whoever spends a year writing on a topic is almost
> > certainly serious
> > about it.
>
> This argument I accept :)

Excellent! I'm glad we have found some common ground.
--
J. B. Rainsberger,
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com :: +1 416 791-8603
Let's write software that people understand
